_**Welcome to Night Vale**_ is a [podcast](/wiki/Podcast "Podcast") presented
as a [radio show](/wiki/Radio_show "Radio show") for the fictional town of
Night Vale, reporting on the strange events that occur within it. The series
was created in 2012 by Joseph Fink and Jeffrey Cranor. Published by Night Vale
Presents since March 15, 2015,[4] the podcast was previously published by
Commonplace Books.[5] Cecil Gershwin Palmer—the [host](/wiki/Radio_personality
"Radio personality"), [main character](/wiki/Protagonist "Protagonist"), and
[narrator](/wiki/First-person_narrative "First-person narrative")—is voiced by
Cecil Baldwin, while secondary characters are sometimes voiced by guest
stars—such as [Dylan Marron](/wiki/Dylan_Marron "Dylan Marron"), who voices
Carlos. The podcast typically airs on the first and fifteenth of every month,
and consists of "news, announcements and advertisements" from the desert
town,[6] located "somewhere in the [Southwestern United
States](/wiki/Southwestern_United_States "Southwestern United States")."[7] In
an interview with [NPR](/wiki/NPR "NPR"), Joseph Fink said that he "came up
with this idea of a town in that desert where all conspiracy theories were
real, and we would just go from there with that understood."[8]

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Welcome_to_Night_Vale&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Production")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Cecil_Baldwin_%28Welcome_to_Night_Vale%29.jpg/220px-
Cecil_Baldwin_%28Welcome_to_Night_Vale%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cecil_Baldwin_\(Welcome_to_Night_Vale\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cecil_Baldwin_\(Welcome_to_Night_Vale\).jpg "Enlarge")

Cecil Baldwin as Cecil in the live episode "The Investigators" during the 2015
UK tour.

See also: [List of Welcome to Night Vale
episodes](/wiki/List_of_Welcome_to_Night_Vale_episodes "List of Welcome to
Night Vale episodes")

Every episode of the podcast includes a piece of music as "the weather", each
by a different independently published artist.[9] The theme and background
instrumental music to the series were created by the musician and composer
Disparition.[10]

In October 2013, _Welcome to Night Vale_ began presenting live shows, which
continued into 2014 with a tour of the West Coast.[11] In addition, it was
announced during the episode "The Auction" that a
[novel](/wiki/Welcome_to_Night_Vale_\(novel\) "Welcome to Night Vale
\(novel\)") would be published in 2015. Fink stated that "it's going to have
all the characters and weird atmosphere that you want from Night Vale, with a
brand new story that explores parts of Night Vale that we just haven't been
able to get into with the podcast".[12][13] When the book became available for
pre-order the following March, it became Amazon's #2 title seven months ahead
of its October release date.[14]

_Welcome to Night Vale_ 's plot consists of longform storytelling.[15]
Individual episodes usually function as standalone narratives and only rarely
contain significant developments in storyline.[16] The writers employ [running
jokes](/wiki/Running_jokes "Running jokes") and [plot arcs](/wiki/Plot_arcs
"Plot arcs"), advanced slowly through the events described in the podcast. For
example, The Glow Cloud, one of the series' most iconic characters, hypnotizes
the townspeople with its colors and noxious gas, making people chant "ALL HAIL
THE MIGHTY GLOW CLOUD", and eventually becomes president of Night Vale's
school board. Another running joke is that the job with the highest death rate
is being an intern at the radio station; the only interns and former interns
who are currently alive include (in order of appearance) Cecil, Chad Bowinger,
Dana Cardinal, Maureen, Vithya and Kareem.

Characters and narratives may emerge and develop slowly, while unrelated
stories may combine to form new plot points.[15][17] Major stories which have
occurred include the development of a romantic relationship between Cecil and
Carlos;[18] the stranding of several characters, including Carlos, in a
"desert otherworld";[19] the invasion of Night Vale by the corporation
StrexCorp, from the rival town of Desert Bluffs, and StrexCorp's eventual
expulsion from Night Vale;[20] the 2014 mayoral elections, with subsequent
terrorist activities by failed mayoral candidates The Faceless Old Woman Who
Secretly Lives in Your Home and Hiram McDaniels;[21] and the complications
surrounding McDaniels' subsequent imprisonment and trial. The series' fourth
anniversary in June 2016 coincided with a two-part climax to the most recent
storyline: the invasion of Night Vale by mysterious strangers, led by a
demonic beagle puppy accidentally summoned from Hell by Chad Bowinger, a
former radio intern. The early plot point of a miniature city buried under the
town's bowling alley resurfaced after this, in addition to the sporadic
appearance of Huntokar, a deer-headed deity with connections to both the tiny
city and Night Vale's unusual nature.

## Guest stars and guest
writers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Welcome_to_Night_Vale&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Guest stars and guest writers")]

  * [Dylan Marron](/wiki/Dylan_Marron "Dylan Marron") as Carlos, Cecil's scientist boyfriend and later husband.
  * [Jasika Nicole](/wiki/Jasika_Nicole "Jasika Nicole") as Dana Cardinal, former Night Vale Community Radio Intern and current Mayor of Night Vale.
  * [Kevin R. Free](/w/index.php?title=Kevin_R._Free&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kevin R. Free \(page does not exist\)") as Kevin, Cecil's Desert Bluffs counterpart obsessed with blood and gore, offsetting his always cheery disposition.
  * [Mara Wilson](/wiki/Mara_Wilson "Mara Wilson") as The Faceless Old Woman Who Secretly Lives in Your Home, a former mayoral candidate and being who simultaneously lives in the homes of all Night Vale residents.
  * [Jackson Publick](/wiki/Jackson_Publick "Jackson Publick") as Hiram McDaniels, a literal five-headed dragon and former mayoral candidate.
  * [Retta](/wiki/Retta "Retta") as Old Woman Josie, Cecil's dearest friend and the only person in town to directly acknowledge the existence of Angels.
  * [Hal Lublin](/wiki/Hal_Lublin "Hal Lublin") as Steve Carlsberg, Cecil's brother-in-law whom he distrusts.
  * Symphony Sanders as Tamika Flynn, a well-read young woman in charge of a teenage militia in the desert.
  * Lauren Sharpe as Lauren Mallard, the former head of StrexCorp.
  * [Maureen Johnson](/wiki/Maureen_Johnson "Maureen Johnson") as Intern Maureen, a disgruntled former Night Vale Community Radio Intern.
  * Mark Gagliardi as John Peters, A local farmer who is always referred to as "John Peters; you know, the farmer?"
  * Kate Jones as Michelle Nguyen, the owner of Dark Owl Records who vehemently disdains anything remotely popular.
  * Desiree Burch as Pamela Winchell, the former Mayor of Night Vale and current Head of Emergency Press Conferences.
  * Emma Frankland as Sheriff Sam, who became sheriff of Night Vale after the previous sheriff mysteriously disappeared.
  * Tina Parker as Huntokar, the goddess who created Night Vale.
  * [Wil Wheaton](/wiki/Wil_Wheaton "Wil Wheaton") as Earl Harlan, a local celebrity chef and childhood friend of Cecil.
  * Meg Bashwhinner as Deb, a sentient patch of haze, who comes on the show to read advertisements. She also provides the voice of "Proverb Lady" who reads the credits at the end of every episode.
  * James Urbaniack as Leonard Burton, the former host of Night Vale Community Radio before Cecil.
  * Mark Evan Janson as Marcus Vanston, an extraordinarily wealthy Night Vale citizen who was turned into an Angel during the mayoral debate.
  * [Molly Quinn](/wiki/Molly_Quinn "Molly Quinn") as Fey, a computer program reading random numbers that eventually becomes sentient. Molly Quinn also voices her creator, Melony Pennington.
  * [Felicia Day](/wiki/Felicia_Day "Felicia Day") as Joanna Rey, a shapeshifting zookeeper.
  * [Jason Webley](/wiki/Jason_Webley "Jason Webley") as Louie Blasko, the former owner of Louie's Music Shop before it burned down and he skipped town.
  * Aliee Chan as Basimah Bashara a young woman whose father has been away fighting the Blood Space War for most of her life.
  * [Dessa](/wiki/Dessa "Dessa") as Sabina, Cecil's cousin.
  * Erica Livingston and Christopher Loar as Maggie and Donald Penebaker, a husband and wife who serve as the voices of the phone tree menus for all services in night vale.
  * Flor De Liz Perez as Lacy, a representative for the Night Vale Department of Water

[Zack Parsons](/wiki/Zack_Parsons "Zack Parsons"), who wrote alongside Fink at
[Something Awful](/wiki/Something_Awful "Something Awful"), has co-written
four episodes: "The Traveler," "A Beautiful Dream," "The Deft Bowman," and
"Lost in the Mail."[22][23] "The Auction" was co-written by [Glen David
Gold](/wiki/Glen_David_Gold "Glen David Gold"),[13] who also contributed
material to "The Woman from Italy."[24]

##
Novels[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Welcome_to_Night_Vale&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Novels")]

### _Welcome to Night
Vale_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Welcome_to_Night_Vale&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Welcome to Night Vale")]

Main article: [Welcome to Night Vale
(novel)](/wiki/Welcome_to_Night_Vale_\(novel\) "Welcome to Night Vale
\(novel\)")

In October 2015 Fink and Cranor released a novel by the same name, _Welcome to
Night Vale_. It is told primarily from the viewpoints of Jackie Fierro and
Diane Crayton, both citizens of Night Vale who have been featured in the
podcast. Critical reception for the book has been positive.[25][26][27]

### _It
Devours!_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Welcome_to_Night_Vale&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: It Devours!")]

In the March 15, 2017 episode of the podcast, Fink announced a second novel,
titled _It Devours!_ , which will deal with Carlos and his team of scientists
investigating the Cult of the Smiling God. It will be released October 17,
2017.[28]

## Night Vale Presents
podcasts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Welcome_to_Night_Vale&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Night Vale Presents podcasts")]

Night Vale Presents, the overall banner for the _Welcome to Night Vale_
podcast, began launching more serial fiction podcasts in early 2016.

The first, _[Alice Isn't Dead](/wiki/Alice_Isn%27t_Dead "Alice Isn't Dead")_,
was written by _Night Vale_ cowriter Joseph Fink, and was performed by [Jasika
Nicole](/wiki/Jasika_Nicole "Jasika Nicole"), who played Dana on _Night Vale_.
The story was presented as monologues broadcast over a trucker [CB
radio](/wiki/Citizens_band_radio "Citizens band radio"), as a woman drives a
truck across America, looking for her missing wife. The first season of 10
episodes was released between March and July, 2016, and a second season began
airing in April 2017.[29]

The second Night Vale Presents podcast was _Within the Wires_ , written by
_Night Vale_ cowriter Jeffrey Cranor and Janina Matthewson, who also performed
the lead character. This story was told as a series of relaxation tapes
prepared for a patient in a mysterious medical center known as "The
Institute." As the story unfolds, it became clear that the narrator of the
tapes had a connection to the patient, and may have had a secret agenda. The
first season of 10 episodes was released between June and November, 2016.[30]

A third podcast, _[The Orbiting Human Circus (of the
Air)](/wiki/The_Orbiting_Human_Circus_\(of_the_Air\) "The Orbiting Human
Circus \(of the Air\)")_ , was released October 12, 2016. This podcast was
written by and stars musician [Julian Koster](/wiki/Julian_Koster "Julian
Koster").[31]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Welcome_to_Night_Vale&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Reception")]

The show has been described as "the news from [Lake
Wobegon](/wiki/Lake_Wobegon "Lake Wobegon") as seen through the eyes of
[Stephen King](/wiki/Stephen_King "Stephen King")", and Christopher Wynn of
_[The Dallas Morning News](/wiki/The_Dallas_Morning_News "The Dallas Morning
News")_ characterized it as "[NPR](/wiki/NPR "NPR") meets [The Mothman
Prophecies](/wiki/The_Mothman_Prophecies_\(film\) "The Mothman Prophecies
\(film\)")".[6] _[The Daily Dot](/wiki/The_Daily_Dot "The Daily Dot")_ 's
Gavia Baker-Whitelaw compared the podcast to being "caught somewhere between
[Weird Twitter](/wiki/Weird_Twitter "Weird Twitter") and 'Tales of the
Unexplained'" and said that it is "well worth a listen—although possibly not
after dark, if you live in a small town yourself".[32] Colin Griffith of _[The
A.V. Club](/wiki/The_A.V._Club "The A.V. Club")_ said the show is "really well
done, offering a surrealist/absurdist (and occasionally existentialist) take
on [community radio](/wiki/Community_radio "Community radio"), with dispatches
from the small, delectably nightmarish desert town of Night Vale".[33] Writing
for _TechGeek_ , Erin Hill considered the uniqueness of the podcast to be "its
presentation of what is ordinary", adding that "many of the things that Cecil
reports goes against our idea of normal, but [everything] is presented in a
manner that makes it seem mundane".[34]

In July 2013, _Welcome to Night Vale_ was ranked second on the top 10 audio
podcasts list on [iTunes](/wiki/ITunes "ITunes"), behind radio program _[This
American Life](/wiki/This_American_Life "This American Life")_.[35] During the
same month, it surpassed _This American Life_ to become first on the podcasts
list, having received 150,000 downloads during a single week.

In December 2013, _The A.V. Club_ ranked the show 7th on its Best Podcasts of
2013 list.[36]

Co-producer Jeffrey Cranor attributed this spike in popularity to both
[Tumblr](/wiki/Tumblr "Tumblr") and fans of the television series
_[Hannibal](/wiki/Hannibal_\(TV_series\) "Hannibal \(TV series\)")_. Max
Sebela, a creative strategist for Tumblr, stated that the fan following began
to "spiral out of control" beginning on July 5, with that week having
"20,000-plus posts about 'Night Vale,' with 183,000-plus individual blogs
participating in the conversation, and 680,000-plus notes".[37] The
[Twitter](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter") account for the podcast has been noted as
having more than 20,000 followers by July 2013.[10]

According to [The Daily Dot](/wiki/The_Daily_Dot "The Daily Dot"), new
listeners primarily come through [fan following](/wiki/Fandom "Fandom") and
word of mouth primarily on [Tumblr](/wiki/Tumblr "Tumblr") with [fan
fiction](/wiki/Fan_fiction "Fan fiction") and fan art focusing on the romantic
relationship between the show's narrator and scientist Carlos.[38] Fans have
published "fanscripts", [transcripts](/wiki/Transcription_\(linguistics\)
"Transcription \(linguistics\)") of the podcast, in order to widen the
accessibility of _Welcome to Night Vale_.[39]

On October 15, 2015 producers Joseph Fink and Jeffrey Cranor were interviewed
on _[The Late Show with Stephen
Colbert](/wiki/The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert "The Late Show with Stephen
Colbert")_ , and Cecil Baldwin appeared for a Community Calendar public
service message for Night Vale.[40] Mike Rugnetta of [PBS](/wiki/PBS "PBS")'s
web show Idea Channel compares the show to horror writer [H.P.
Lovecraft](/wiki/H.P._Lovecraft "H.P. Lovecraft")'s style of writing about
fear of what we don't know. He says "But Night Vale turns Lovecraft's
'unimaginable terror' into 'drab mundanity'."
